Patients with a novel sensory and motor neuropathy bear a c.472G>C (p.P158A) variant in NAMPT ( A + B C NAMPT D NAMPT NAMPT NAMPT E F G H In this study, we identified a genetic variant of homozygous missense mutation (c.472C>G, p.P158A) in the coding region of NAMPT RESULTS A novel sensory and motor neuropathy associated with a c.472G>C (p.P158A) variant in NAMPT We conducted whole exome sequencing (WES) on genomic DNA extracted from two siblings, a 25-year-old sister (proband) and her 15.5-year-old brother, as well as their parents ( Fig. 1, B to D HEATR5B MVK MYO18A, NAMPT Notably, variants within MVK Table 1 MYO18A HEATR5B Table 1. Upon meticulous consideration, the homozygous variant of NAMPT + 16 NAMPT NAMPT Fig. 1, C and D Fig. 1E The siblings bearing the homozygous p.P158A NAMPT variant exhibited a spectrum of symptoms characteristic of an undiagnosed neurological disease ( Fig. 1, F to H NAMPT Table 2 Table 2. Clinical features of the patients. Variable Clinical features  Motor coordination Impaired  Muscle Atrophy and weakness  Foot and hand Deformity  Sensation Diminished superficial and deep sensation from the lower extremities  Eye mobility Inward nystagmus  Retina Thinning but without degeneration  Babiński sign Positive  Speech Indistinct  Mental retardation Mild  Brain MRI Normal  EEG recording Normal Reductions in enzyme activity and cellular bioenergetics by p.P158A mutation A crystal structure study revealed that the human NAMPT (hNAMPT) protein is a dimer and the P158 residue is located away from the enzyme’s active center ( Fig. 2A 18 Fig. 2B V max K m Fig. 2, C to E 19 20 T m T m T m Fig. 2, F to H Fig. 2. The p.P158A mutation in NAMPT reduces its enzyme activity and cellular bioenergetics. ( A B C E V max K m n F H dF dT T m T m P t I J K n L O + + n P P Next, we studied cellular bioenergetics in C-FBs (LD), C-FBs (LH), and P-FBs. Although these FBs exhibited comparable morphological features ( Fig. 2I + + Fig. 2, J to O Disrupted systemic metabolic homeostasis in patient blood plasma Human plasma is commonly used for medical diagnosis ( 21 22 Fig. 3, A to D Fig. 3E 23 24 + Fig. 3F 21 Fig. 3. Patient blood plasma exhibit disrupted systemic metabolic homeostasis. ( A D E F + + G H P P P t In human blood plasma from healthy subjects, certain metabolites exhibit remarkably low variability characterized by a small coefficient of variation (CV), while metabolites displaying high variability tend to associate with elevated degrees of molecular modifications (e.g., increased number of methyl groups) ( 21 21 25 Fig. 3, G and H Fig. 3G + l 26 27 28 30 d Fig. 3H l l l 31 Mitochondrial dysfunction and abnormalities in P-FBs We determined the effects of the p.P158A mutation on mitochondrial function using a Seahorse analyzer. In oxygen consumption rate (OCR) analysis, P-FBs displayed significantly reduced spare, basal, maximal, and ATP production–linked respirations but did not affect proton leak–related respiration as compared with the C-FBs ( Fig. 4, A and B Fig. 4, C and D Fig. 4, E and F Fig. 4. P-FBs show mitochondrial dysfunction and abnormalities. ( A B C D E F p G H I J n K L N + + + O Q + + + P P P NAD + Fig. 4, G and H + Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to identify morphological alterations on the mitochondria in P-FBs ( Fig. 4I 32 33 Fig. 4J Fig. 4K To further validate the effect of the p.P158A mutation in NAMPT protein on bioenergetics and metabolic function at cellular levels, we used CRISPR-Cas9 genome-editing method to generate isogenic FBs. We generated multiple (patient-like) isogenic FBs harboring c.472C>G in NAMPT Fig. 4, L and M Fig. 4, O and P + Fig. 4, N and Q Altered metabolomic and lipidomic profiles in P-FBs Next, we conducted metabolomic study to compare metabolomic profiling between P-FBs and C-FBs (LD) due to the comparable bioenergetic results of C-FBs (LD) and C-FBs (LH). A total of 106 metabolites were identified (table S2). Our results unveiled distinct phenotypic patterns between the P-FBs and C-FBs (LD) ( Fig. 5, A to D + + Fig. 5, E to J + Fig. 5E + Fig. 5F + l Fig. 5G d Fig. 5I Fig. 5H Fig. 5J Fig. 5K Fig. 5. P-FBs show altered metabolomic and lipidomic profiles. P-FBs show adaptive transcriptional responses and increased oxidative stress. ( A G P adj q q H I J K L O + + P S P P P Oxidative stress is widely considered one of the major mechanisms contributing to the progression of neurodegenerative diseases ( 52 40 41 45 Fig. 6, H and I Fig. 6, J and K Given the pivotal role of NAD + + 11 12 + Fig. 6, L to O Fig. 6, P and Q Bioenergetic defects and impaired synaptic function in p.P158A-NAMPT mutant mice To study functional consequences of the p.P158A NAMPT variant at cellular and organismal levels, we generated a homozygous p.P158A-NAMPT mutant mouse model (NAMPT P158A/P158A Fig. 7A Fig. 7, B and C + + + + Fig. 7, D to H Fig. 7I Fig. 7. p.P158A-NAMPT mutant mice exhibit reduced bioenergetics and impaired synaptic function. ( A P158A/P158A B C N D H + + + + I J K L M R S V W Z P P P t Given the decreased expression of synaptic proteins in the cortex of mutant mice, we studied the electrophysiological properties of corticocortical neurons (CCNs) and corticospinal neurons (CSNs) ( Fig 7J 53 55 Fig. 7, K and L Fig. 7, M to R Fig. 7, S to V Fig. 7, W to Z Because the patients exhibited sensory motor dysfunction, we conducted a battery of motor behavioral tests of adult mice including rotarod, hanging wire, grip strength, and open field tests. Adult p.P158A-NAMPT mutant mice had no motor function deficits compared to WT mice (fig. S10, A to E). In metabolic health study, adult mutant mice also exhibited similar rectal body temperature reduction during cold exposure, glucose tolerance, and insulin resistance to age-matched WT mice (fig. S10, F to H). Thus, our results from the mouse model demonstrated that p.P158A mutation in NAMPT was associated with the reduction in bioenergetics and the impaired excitability and glutamatergic synaptic output within the motor cortex and to the spinal cord. MN degeneration and gliosis in p.P158A-NAMPT mutant mice Lower MNs in the spinal cord innervate muscle fibers, control motor function, and degenerate in MN disease. At this end, we conducted immunostaining of lumbar 3 to 5 (L3-5) spinal cords with antibodies against choline acetyl transferase (ChAT), NeuN, and MAP2 to examine MN degeneration of aged mutant and WT mice ( Fig. 8 16 56 Fig. 8, E and F Fig. 8, G to I Fig. 8. p.P158A-NAMPT mutant mice exhibit MN degeneration and gliosis in the spinal cord. ( A D E F G I P P t DISCUSSION Despite numerous human NAMPT NAMPT Several symptoms of this MINA syndrome appear to overlap with those of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT), the most common hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy ( 57 58 Given NAMPT’s crucial role in NAD + + + + 8 59 61 62 64 Using NAMPT P158A/P158A NAMPT 16 65 67 + + 68 69 + 70 71 + + 72 74 75 + 76 + 77 + 78 79 + On the other hand, although these mutant mice did not exhibit motor functional deficits and metabolic health problems under normal conditions, it is possible that subtle motor function deficits and metabolic derangements could be detected upon more sensitive in vivo assays such as compound muscle action potential, tetanic muscle contractility, and motor evoked potential ( 80 83 84 85 For genetic diseases, gene therapy and small molecules are important avenues for therapeutic development. Gene therapy holds the promise of durable, sometimes permanent, results, by replacing or editing faulty genes. On the other hand, small-molecule medicine has the advantage of flexible use but often requires life-long intervention. In our current study, we demonstrated the efficacy of NMN and P7C3 in restoring cellular bioenergetics and function of P-FBs. P7C3 compounds elevate NAD levels within cells and the brain and protect against axonal injury after total body irradiation ( 86 89 + + 90 While it has been established that NAD + + + 91 92 2+ 93 + 2+ + 2+ 2+ + + 91 Although our findings from the mutant mouse model indicate that the p.P158A mutation in the brain NAMPT protein may play an important role in pathology, we acknowledge the possibility that reduction in NAD + + In summary, the current study identified a previously unknown genetic variant of NAMPT that causes sensory and motor neuropathy, broadening our understanding of NAD + MATERIALS AND METHODS Whole exome sequencing Genomic DNA from siblings of a 25-year-old sister (proband) and a 15.5-year-old brother as well as their parents (Warsaw, Poland) were extracted from the peripheral blood with QIAamp DNA Blood Mini Kit (catalog no. 51104, QIAGEN, Hilden, Germany). Library preparation for the WES was performed on the siblings’ DNA samples with the SureSelectXT Human All Exon v5 (Agilent, Santa Clara, CA, USA). Subsequently, a paired-end index sequencing (2 × 100) was performed on the HiSeq 1500 sequencer (Illumina Inc., San Diego, CA, USA) to obtain 87,232,798 reads for the male sibling (93.2% of target bases were covered at a minimum of 20×, whereas 97.7% had coverage of a minimum of 10×; mean depth of 92×) and 102,246,504 reads for the female sibling (94.1% of target bases were covered at a minimum of 20×, whereas 98% had coverage of a minimum of 10×; mean depth of 101×). The obtained raw data were processed with the pipeline described previously. Sequencing of genomic DNA from FBs Genomic DNA from control and patient FBs were extracted, and the DNA fragments containing NAMPT were amplified using PCR with primers 5′-TCTGGAATGCACAGCAGG-3′ (forward) and 5′-TGGCTATCCATCTGTCCATCC-3′ (reverse) followed by digestion with HpyCH4V restriction enzyme. The fragments of 432 base pairs (bp) from control and 362 bp from patient were purified for Sanger DNA sequencing using the reverse primer in PCR. Molecular modeling and prediction of hNAMPT protein The crystal structure of hNAMPT together with NMN was downloaded from the Structure database in the NCBI website with the protein data bank ID of 2gvg [J.A. Khan, X. Tao, L. Tong. Molecular basis for the inhibition of human NMPRTase, a novel target for anticancer agents. Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 13 www.3dsbiovia.com/products/collaborative-science/biovia-discovery-studio/visualization-download.php Subcloning of WT hNAMPT into the pET28a vector and site-directed mutagenesis This was accomplished using the FastCloning method ( 94 Table 3 5 E. coli Table 3. Primers for cloning and site-directed mutagenesis Primer names Primer sequences  pET28a_ATG_R 5′-CATGGTATATCTCCTTCTTAAAGT-3′  pET28a_ATG_F 5′-TAGGAATTCGAGCTCCGTCG-3′  hNAMPT_pET_F_His 5′-CGCGCGGCAGCCATATGAATCCTGCGGCAGAAG-3′  hNAMPT_pET_R_no His 5′-TCGACGGAGCTCGAATTCCTAATGATGTGCTGCTTCCAGTTC-3′  hNAMPT_P158A_F 5′-CAGTCCTGGTATGCAATCACAGTGGCCACAAATTC-3′  hNAMPT_P158A_R 5′-TGATTGCATACCAGGACTGAACAAGAATAG-3′ The p.P158A mutation was introduced in pET28a-hNAMPT plasmid to obtain pET28a-p.P158A-hNAMPT plasmid by the QuikChange mutagenesis method using one pair of mutagenic primers hNAMPT_P158A_F and hNAMPT_P158A_R (table S1). The PCR amplification for mutagenesis was essentially the same as that for the subcloning as described above, except for a longer extension time of 7.5 min at 72°C. After agarose gel confirmation of the PCR products, 1 μl of the Dpn I digested PCR product was transformed into the NEB 5αF competent cells. The miniprepared DNA plasmids were digested with Xba I to confirm the DNA before sequencing. The p.P158A mutation in the DNA construct was confirmed by Sanger DNA sequencing. Recombinant hNAMPT protein expression and purification pET28a-hNAMPT (WT) and pET28a-p.P158A-hNAMPT plasmids were individually transformed into BL21(DE3) chemically competent cells (catalog no. CMC0014-4X40UL, Sigma-Aldrich) and then plated onto kanamycin agar plate. Individual colonies were picked up and grew overnight in 2 ml of LB with kanamycin (50 μg/ml) in 5-ml culture tubes. In the morning, the prewarmed LB (100 ml) was inoculated with the overnight culture, incubated at 37°C for 3 hours, and followed by isopropyl-β- d g g Enzymatic activity and PTS assays of recombinant WT and p.P158A mutant NAMPT proteins The enzymatic activities of WT and p.P158A mutant NAMPT proteins were determined by one-step reaction method using NAMPT activity assay kit (catalog no. ab221819, Abcam) in the presence of different concentrations of the substrate NAM while the other substrates PRPP (0.5 mM) and ATP (1 mM) were present in reaction mixtures. Optical density (OD) at 450 nm was recorded using SpectraMax 190 (Molecular Devices) with the kinetic mode at 30°C for 120 min with readings every 5 min. The reaction velocity ( V V max K m V PTS assay was conducted similarly to the published studies ( 19 20 Fig. 2J dF dT T m Fig. 2K −1 A26209 Culture and biochemical assays of patient and control FBs The human FBs were isolated from skin donated by patient (the proband; P-FBs) and healthy individuals LD and LH, namely, C-FBs (LD) and C-FBs (LH) of Caucasians of Polish origin. Donors have given informed and written consent for their samples to be used for research. The skin samples were digested by dispase to eliminate keratinocytes and then cultured in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium (DMEM) supplemented with 10% of fetal bovine serum (FBS) and antibiotics (no collagenase digestion) in a 5% CO 2 For NAMPT activity assay, FBs were cultured in 75-ml flasks. Upon at least 90% confluence, culture medium was removed, and FBs were washed with fresh cold 1× phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) for one time. After washing, fresh cold 1× PBS was added to the flask and cells were detached with cell scraper. Cell suspension was removed from the flask and centrifuged at 4500 g g g Assays for NAD + + + + 5 6 8 16 OCR and ECAR analyses OCR and ECAR analyses of FBs were conducted using a Seahorse XFe96 extracellular flux analyzer (Agilent Technologies, CA, USA) as described previously ( 8 16 l 2 p l 2 4 + Metabolomic analysis of human blood plasma and FBs Sample preparations Blood plasma Blood samples were donated by patients and healthy individuals. The blood samples were centrifuged at 1000 g Cultured control and patient FBs FBs in six-well plates were washed with 1 ml of cold PBS twice, and 300 μl of prechilled 80% methanol was added to each well. Cells were quickly scraped with a cell scraper, transferred into tubes, vortexed thoroughly for 30 s, and kept in −80°C until use. Methanol and water should be LC-MS grade. LC-MS metabolomics Targeted and steady-state metabolomic analyses were collectively done at one time for accurate measurement as in our previous studies ( 47 95 Shotgun lipidomic analysis of lipids from FBs Shotgun lipidomics were performed as described previously ( 34 36 96 RNA-seq and analysis RNA sequencing RNA-seq of FBs was conducted by Novogene (Houston, CA, USA). Total RNA was extracted using TRIzol Reagent (catalog no. 15596026, Thermo Fisher Scientific) according to the manufacturer’s instruction. Samples with high RNA quality were used to construct poly(A) selected paired-end sequencing libraries (150 bp) using Illumina TruSeq Stranded mRNA sample preparation kits (catalog no. RS-122-2101, Illumina, San Diego, CA, USA). The constructed sequencing libraries were subject to sequencing with Illumina NovaSeq 6000 platform. Before assembly, reads containing sequencing adaptors, sequencing primers, and sequences with quality score Q 97 98 Identification of differentially expressed genes and analysis Empirical analysis of digital gene expression in R (edgeR) package v3.12.1 in the Bioconductor was used to analyze differentially expressed genes (DEGs) in the assembled transcriptome ( 99 P adj P adj 2 z Gene set enrichment analysis The mechanisms underlying the relationship between NAD metabolism and cell death were explored with GSEA using preranked gene list ( 51 100 101 2 10 P 51 95 www.gsea-msigdb.org/gsea/index.jsp q q q Western blotting analysis WB was used to analyze protein levels in FBs and mouse brain following the protocol described in our previous studies ( 7 8 43 102 103 8 Mitochondrial structural analysis by TEM P-FBs, C-FBs (LD), and C-FBs (LH) were cultured for 5 days. Cells were washed with 1× PBS for 5 min before collecting them using a cell scraper. Cells were then centrifuged at 12,500 g 95 Fixed pellets were rinsed with 100 mM sodium cacodylate buffer (pH 7.35) (Sigma-Aldrich) and 130 mM sucrose. Secondary fixation was performed using 1% osmium tetroxide (Ted Pella, Inc., CA, USA) in 2-mercaptoethanol buffer using a PELCO BioWave (Ted Pella, Inc.) operated at 100 W for 1 min. Specimens were next incubated at 4°C for 1 hour and then rinsed with cacodylate buffer and further with distilled water. En bloc staining was performed using 1% aqueous uranyl acetate and incubated at 4°C overnight and then rinsed with distilled water. Using the PELCO BioWave, a graded dehydration series (per exchange, 100 W for 40 s) was performed using ethanol and transitioned into acetone, and dehydrated specimens were then infiltrated with EPON resin (250 W for 3 min) and polymerized at 60°C overnight. Sections were cut to a thickness of 75 nm using an ultramicrotome (Ultracut UCT, Leica Microsystems, Germany) and a diamond knife (DiATOME, PA, USA). Images were acquired with a JEM-1400 TEM (JEOL, MA, USA) at 80 kV on a Gatan UltraScan 1000 charge-coupled device (CCD) (Gatan, Inc., CA, USA). Mitochondria were analyzed using ImageJ [National Institutes of Health (NIH)]. Area, perimeter, Feret’s diameter, major axis, minor axis, and shape descriptors (circularity, roundness, solidity, and aspect ratio) were assessed. Feret’s diameter is the longest distance between two points along the outlined area and is also called caliper distance. Major axis and minor axis length are determined from the Fit Ellipse selection. Circularity is a score from 0 to 1, with 1 indicating a perfect circle and decreases as the shape becomes more rod-like. Roundness equals (4 × area)/[π × (major axis) 2 DHE staining To determine the effect of the p.P158A mutation in NAMPT on oxidative stress in FBs, we evaluated the ROS of FBs using DHE staining ( 104 F cum Mice All procedures in the following were performed according to the NIH Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals and approved by the University of Missouri Animal Care Quality Assurance Committee (protocol number 57121). The p.P158A-NAMPT mutant mice with background of C57BL/6J mice were generated as described in Fig. 7A P158A/P158A P158A Stereotaxic injections of retrograde adeno-associated virus vectors The cortical neurons were retrogradely labeled by injection of tracers for visualization purposes, as described in a previous study, with a slight modification ( 53 2 13 13 Electrophysiological recordings of brain slices All procedures were described in our previous study ( 105 2 2 2 4 3 2 2 2 2 2 2 2 2 Immunostaining of spinal cords The procedure for immunostaining of L3-5 spinal cord slices was described in our previous studies ( 16 106 P36931 16 106 Body weight measurement and behavioral tests For body weight measurement, mouse was placed in a plastic box with lid and weighed by a digital balance. For behavioral tests, all the animals were taken out from the animal room in their home cages to the behavior test room and habituated for at least 30 min. After the pretraining was finished twice for each type of behavior tests, hanging wire, rotarod, grip force, and open field tests were conducted as described in previous studies ( 16 103 107 Acute cold exposure Mice were placed individually into unbedded clean cages. Rectal temperature was recorded before entry into 4°C, and 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, 3, 3.5, and 4 hours in 4°C environment. Glucose tolerance test and insulin tolerance test For the glucose tolerance test, mice were fasted overnight (16 hours), and blood glucose was measured with a glucometer (Contour next EZ glucose meter) from a drop of blood obtained from tail vein puncture. After fasting blood glucose was measured, mice were administered glucose solution [3 g/kg body weight (BW)] via intraperitoneal injection, and blood glucose levels were assessed 0.5, 1, 1.5, and 2 hours afterward. For the insulin tolerance test, mice were fasted for 4 hours, and blood glucose was measured with a glucometer from a drop of blood obtained from tail vein puncture. After fasting blood glucose was measured, mice were then administered insulin solution (0.5 U/g BW) via intraperitoneal injection, and blood glucose was assessed 0.5, 1, 1.5, and 2 hours afterward.
